dataset.title: Germination and storage of Trema cannabina seeds

abstract.para: Storage behaviour and germination enhancement of Trema cannabina seeds (Ulmaceae) were studied. Freshly harvested mature seeds germinated to about 70% in 12 weeks at 30/20°C alternating temperatures. Moist stratification at 4°C prior to incubation of fresh seeds significantly increased germination rate and the mean germination time decreased from 53 days to 23 days in 2 months, and to 17 days in 5 months. Immersing seeds in concentrated sulphuric acid for 80-90 minutes significantly increased germination percentage and rate. Seeds of T. cannabina survived desiccation to both 4.9% and 9.6% moisture contents (MC) (fresh weight basis) and storage at 4 and 15°C, respectively, for 24 months without a loss of germinability, whereas those that were desiccated to 14.4% and 16.2% MC lost their germination from 65% to 0-35% under the same storage condition and period. Seeds stored at -20°C with 4.9% and 9.6% MC drastically reduced their germination from 65% to below 10% in one year and seeds at the same subzero temperature with 14.4% or higher MC did not survive in one month. Thus, T. cannabina exhibited intermediate seed storage behaviour.

section.title: Seeds
section.para: Fruits of T. cannabina become reddish orange color when they are mature. Mature
fruits (drupes) were harvested from natural trees growing in Shitu (24°52’N; 121°45’E),
Taipei county in northern Taiwan in September, 2002. The above seed lot was tested for
germination, stratification and storage at various temperatures. An other seed lot treated
with sulphuric acid scarification for germination enhancement was harvested in Longtan
(24°51’N; 121°12’E), Taoyuan county, in October, 2006. Approximately 44,000 seeds
were collected from Shitu, Taipei county. Fruits were macerated by hand in water, and
the clean, sunken seeds were allowed to dry for 8 hours at room temperature, after which
they were stored temporarily in sealed containers at 4°C before treatments. MC of fresh
seeds was determined by oven-dry method for 17 hours at 103°C with 4 replications of
about 150 seeds each and calculated on a fresh weight basis (fwb) (International Seed
Testing Association, 1999).

section.title: Imbibition
section.para: Rate of water uptake was determined in the Trema seeds that were collected in October,
2006. Each of 20 non-scarified and scarified (cut at the point away from embryonic axis)
seeds was weighed individually to the nearest 0.1 mg at time 0 and incubated at ambient
laboratory temperature (~25°C) on Whatman No. 1 filter paper in Petri dishes moistened
with distilled water. Following the procedure seed mass was measured at 8-hour intervals
for the first 24 hours and then every 24 hours for the next 144 hours. Percentage water
uptake was calculated as follows:
where Ws = increase in seed mass, Wi = seed mass after imbibition and Wd = initial seed
mass (Chien et al., 2006).

section.title: Dry treatment and storage
section.para: Fresh seeds of T. cannabina were dried in a sealed container (40 × 25 × 25 cm) with a
fan inside for air circulation. Temperature and relative humidity outside the container
were maintained at 15°C and 50-55%, respectively. To reduce the MC from 18% of fresh
seeds to 10%, seeds in the sealed container with silica gel inside were taken out and
MC was measured over time to obtain desired MCs. To reduce the MC below 10%,
seeds were placed in the same container with molecule sieves inside (Chen et al., 2006).
Thus, the MCs of 4.9, 9.6, 14.4 and 16.2% were obtained. Dried seeds were sealed in
laminated aluminium foil and stored at 15, 4 and -20°C. After 0, 1, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20 and
24 months, 4 replications of 50 seeds each of these storage temperatures were tested for
germination. Thus, the total number of treatments for seeds of T. cannabina was 96 (4
MCs × 3 temperatures × 8 storage periods).

section.title: Cold stratification
section.para: Fresh seeds of T. cannabina were mixed with moist sphagnum, sealed inside polyethylene
bags (0.04 mm in thickness) and stored at 4°C in darkness. At monthly intervals, seeds
were removed from storage for germination test for a total of 12 months. A treatment
consisted of 4 replications of 50 seeds each. The sphagnum used for treatments was cut
into small pieces. Water content of the sphagnum was about 400% of its dry mass.

section.title: Sulphuric acid and physical scarification
section.para: Fresh seeds were treated with concentrated sulphuric acid (95-97% by acidimetric assay,
Merck, Germany) for 10-minute intervals up to 90 minutes prior to germination. The
treated seeds were immediately washed with tap water 5 times and soaked in distilled
water for 6 hours and were then mixed with moist sphagnum and incubated at 30/20°C
with 12 hours of fluorescent light (80-100 μMol m-2 s-1, 400~700 nm) at the higher
temperature. The concentrated sulphuric acid was diluted to half (48-49%) by distilled
water and was also used for testing seed germination using the same method as above.
Each treatment consisted of three replications of 50 seeds. The number of germinated
seeds was recorded weekly and results expressed as percentage germination.

section.title: Germination tests
section.para: Fresh, dry-stored and cold moist-stored seeds of T. cannabina were mixed with moist
sphagnum (small pieces) in sealed polyethylene bags (0.04 mm in thickness) and then
incubated at alternating temperatures of 30/20°C (12/12 h) with 12 hours of fluorescent
light (80-100 μMol m-2 s-1, 400~700 nm) at the higher temperature. Germination, i.e.
radicle at least 5 mm long, was recorded weekly for 12 weeks. Results are expressed as
germination percentage and as mean germination time (MGT) in days (Naylor, 1981).
MGT = (Σniti)/N, where ni is the number of seeds germinated in ti days from the beginning
of the test, and N is the total number of germinated seeds at the end of the test. MGT is a
measure of the rate of germination and of the sharpness of the germination peak.

section.title: Statistical analysis
section.para: Germination percentages (mean ± SE) were calculated, and means were compared by
analysis of variance (ANOVA) and by least significant difference (LSD) test at the 5%
level of significance (SAS, 2004).
